awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Development and empirical tests of a mechanistic multi-host, multi-pathogen theory
awd_abstract_narration:
Most plants and animals can be infected by very small organisms that can make them sick.  The infected plant or animal is called a "host" and the infecting organism is called a "pathogen".  The interaction between hosts and pathogens is important to understand because it often determines one's health. Scientists are now becoming aware that the host-pathogen interaction is more complicated because one host can be infected by many pathogens, all of whom interact with each other as well as with the host.  Likewise, one type of pathogen can infect several types of hosts, and how one host responds can influence whether another host becomes infected.  Figuring out how all this plays out in Nature requires carefully designed experiments and mathematical models and this project provides both.  Developing a deeper understanding of hosts and pathogens is critical because humans are dramatically altering the biological world, introducing new types of hosts and pathogens in some areas and removing them from others. Understanding how such gains and losses of organisms influences the spread of disease is important to the fields of conservation science and public health. This research program will train undergraduate, graduate, and high school students in the fields of disease ecology and mathematical biology, and will engage the public through a variety of outreach activities. 

Humans are impacting biodiversity patterns globally and these changes can influence the risk and prevalence of infectious diseases. The goal of this project is to develop a mechanistic multi-host multi-pathogen epidemiological theory that explains how between-host and between-pathogen competition jointly shape disease dynamics.  To determine how competition alters the amplification or dilution of diseases, mathematical models will be developed and tested using planktonic species and their associated pathogens via laboratory based mesocosm and field experiments. This work will both extend current theory on multi-host and multi-pathogen communities as well as unify theory developed independently for diseases with different transmission modes.  The theory-data pairing approach of this study is likely to generate important advances in epidemiological theory and disease ecology. This work will also yield insight into how future alterations to diversity will affect disease outbreaks in humans and wildlife.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
It is unfortunately abundantly clear that an individual species can be infected by a wide range of pathogens, and that a single pathogen can move from one host species to another with devastating consequences. The goal of this project was to better understand these multihost-multipathogen interactions, aiming to understand how interactions between host species and between pathogen species alter overall outcomes, including the likelihood of a disease outbreak occurring and the harm suffered by infected hosts.

As part of this project, we explored several key factors that might influence the outcomes of coinfection, which is when a single host individual is infected by two pathogens. Our studies found that the relative doses of the two pathogens influenced whether a host became infected or co-infected, which, in turn, had strong impacts on host lifespan and reproduction. They also revealed that host age could dramatically alter the interactions between coinfecting pathogens, with very different outcomes of pathogen competition within hosts, with impacts on epidemic dynamics.

We also collected and analyzed a rich dataset on multihost-multipathogen interactions in inland lakes. This dataset is valuable both for helping us understand these ecosystems and because interactions between lake organisms and their pathogens are a model system for understanding host-pathogen interactions more broadly. In one analysis of this dataset, we found that applying approaches from network modeling can identify hosts that may be particularly important for cross-species transmission (also known as ‘spillover’ of pathogens).

A particularly interesting finding of this research is that the effects of pathogens can extend across generations. We exposed some hosts to a microsporidian pathogen and then collected their offspring, which were not exposed to a pathogen. Those offspring had greatly reduced fitness as compared to the offspring of hosts that were not exposed to a pathogen; we term this result ‘transgenerational virulence’ because virulence is the harm caused by pathogens to their hosts, and, in this case, the primary effect occurs in the offspring of exposed hosts. Notably, the fitness reduction in the offspring is comparable to the fitness reduction caused within a generation by a different (fungal) pathogen that is generally considered to be highly virulent. These results suggest that pathogens might be having larger and longer acting impacts than previously recognized.

Thirteen undergraduates worked on this project. Two of these undergraduates (both from a minority-serving institution) are coauthors on a manuscript that has already been published and four additional students are coauthors on manuscripts that are either in review or near submission. Many of the students who worked on this project are from groups traditionally underrepresented in the sciences. This award also supported the work of four graduate students in the lab. One of these students is now an Assistant Professor, and another is an Instructor at an HBCU. Another student now works for the US Centers for Disease Control (CDC) and the fourth is a postdoctoral scientist working in public health and epidemiology. The award also supported the work of two postdoctoral scientists. One of these is still a postdoctoral scientist, while the other has moved on to a position at the US CDC. Thus, one outcome of this work is training scientists who are well-equipped to tackle challenges in public health and epidemiology.

We also led outreach events related to this project. This included: leading and running a week-long course on data literacy for high school students from Ypsilanti, Detroit, and Southfield, MI, and developing and leading training modules related to field biology and aquatic ecology for incoming students.

Nine publications from this work have already appeared in print, with an additional publications under review. Several other publications are currently in preparation for submission, and more will be prepared in the future.
